Graphical abstract The chemisorption and hydrogenating properties of Ni/SiO2 catalysts prepared by the hydrazine method then calcined at 400°C with various times were investigated. Metal dispersion and activity in benzene hydrogenation increased with increasing calcination time whereas desorbed amounts of hydrogen significantly decreased. Dilution of a calcined sample by the support led to a sharp increase of both hydrogen storage by the support and catalytic activity. Metal dispersion and hydrogen storage capacity influenced the reaction mechanisms of hydrogenation of benzene which, therefore, is believed to occur on the metal phase or/and on the support by the hydrogen spillover mechanism. The metal active phase would be composed of an ensemble of metallic and oxidized nickel species. Keywords Nickel catalysts Hydrogen storage Benzene hydrogenation Calcination Hydrogen spillover 1 Introduction In a previous paper we reported results on H2 chemisorption and hydrogenating properties of metallic nickel nanoparticles supported on silica of low surface area [1]. The catalysts were prepared by reduction in aqueous hydrazine. The activity in benzene hydrogenation and hydrogen storage of the support depended on the metal loading and thermal treatments. Remarkably, after calcination in air then re-activation in H2 atmosphere, the catalysts became more active but stored less hydrogen than the as-prepared catalysts. The results obtained were explained using the hydrogen spillover mechanism [2,3]. Since then this mechanism has been critically revisited by Prins et al. [4,5] and Choi et al. [6,7]. These authors report more subtile explanations on the nature of the spillover phenomena and particularly for metal catalysts supported over non reducible oxides. For Prins et al. [5] the surface diffusion of hydrogen species by the spillover mechanism is not possible with non reducible oxides (e.g. MgO, SiO2, zeolite) because the H-spiltover species are strongly bonded to a metal particle and only moderately to a non reducible support. As a result these species cannot be implied in the hydrogenation of unsaturated molecules unless the oxide contained defects or carbon deposits [8]. As to Choi et al. [6], they defined the conditions where the hydrogen spillover concept does hold with non reducible support oxides. The model catalyst was Pt particles encapsulated in a zeolite framework where the respective dimensions of the metal particles and zeolite pores allowed selective diffusion of H2 over various organic molecules. As a result the observed catalytic activities could be unambiguously attributed to catalytic reactions via H spillover at the external surface of the zeolite. The occurrence of H spillover also requires the presence of abundant surface hydroxyls. Effect of calcination on the spillover effect have been reported for metal catalysts supported on non reducible oxides. For Cęckiewicz and Delmon [9], calcination enhances the spillover effect in the hydrogenation of benzene over Pt/γ-Al2O3 diluted with the support because it removes the carbon impurities deposited on the catalyst surface. Contrary to that Vannice and Neikam [10] did not observe the spillover effect in the hydrogenation of benzene over Pd/Al2O3 catalysts diluted with the support and pre-calcined. For the authors, the spillover effect, when claimed for benzene hydrogenation, would be due to carbon impurities which allow the diffusion of surface H-species [5]. Miller et al. [11] reported that the amounts of hydrogen desorbing at high temperature over Pt/SiO2 (Al2O3, zeolites) decreased after a thermal treatment in air. However, the hydrogen molecules were not ascribed to spillover effect but to H-species incorporated in the support during the catalyst preparation. These new insights on the spillover phenomena [4–7] prompted us to confirm and re-examine our previous results on the effect of calcination on catalytic activity. Moreover, effect of calcination on the surface and catalytic properties of metal catalysts prepared by a chemical method has not been reported to our best knowledge. Such investigation would enlarge the knowledge of the role of calcination on the reactivity of metal supported catalysts [12,13]. A Ni0/SiO2 catalyst, prepared by the hydrazine method, was calcined at 400°C with various times. For each sample, the degree of reduction by O2 adsorption, H2 adsorption, H2 temperature programmed desorption (H2-TPD) and activity in benzene hydrogenation were evaluated. One sample was diluted by the support and similarly investigated. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Nickel acetate tetrahydrate (99.0%, Fluka) and aqueous hydrazine 24–26% (_99.0%, Fluka) were used as received. The silica support (Chempur, 99.99%, 15m2 g−1 and grains of 325mesh) was pretreated in air at 500°C for 10h before use. The catalyst precursor was prepared by impregnating at room temperature a suspension of silica in a solution of nickel acetate, evaporating at 80°C in vacuum then drying at 100°C. The solid precursor was introduced in a solution of hydrazine and heated up to 70°C. The black solution obtained was cooled, filtered and washed with ethanol. The resulting filtrate was dried under vacuum and stored under argon. The final solid contained 1%Ni. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The nickel composition of the catalyst was determined on a Varian AA1275 atomic absorption spectrophotometer. The XRD patterns I(θ) were recorded at a classical θ/2θ diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation. Chemisorption experiments were carried out with a sample of 0.1g on a pulse chromatographic microreactor equipped with the catharometric detector of a microchromatograph (AT M200, Hewlett Packard) fitted with molecular sieve columns and MTI software. The utilized gases were purchased from Air Liquide. Oxygen traces were eliminated from argon (99.995%) and hydrogen (99.995%) by using a manganese oxytrap (Engelhardt). Diluted H2 and O2 in argon and synthetic air were used as received. Each sample was pre-treated with H2 pure (100mLmin−1/2h/300°C), purged under argon atmosphere (100mLmin−1/2h) and cooled to room temperature. After that, gaseous hydrogen (100ppm in argon) was injected in the reactor every 2min until saturation of the sample. Then, the hydrogen saturated sample was purged at room temperature under argon for 2h, a time after which no hydrogen (<1ppm) was detected in the exit gas. It was subsequently submitted to a TPD under same gas (50mLmin−1) with a heating rate of 7.5°Cmin−1 up to 800°C. O2 chemisorption was used to evaluate the degree of reduction of calcined samples, according to the literature data [14]. After calcination each sample was submitted to same H2 heat treatment as above, cooled to room temperature, purged then flowed with gaseous oxygen (150ppm of O2 in helium) every 2min until saturation. 2.3 Catalytic tests and kinetic study The gas-phase hydrogenation reaction was carried out in a quartz fixed-bed reactor after activation under hydrogen as described above for chemisorption studies. The catalytic tests were conducted with a sample of 0.1g and a feed gas of 1% C6H6/H2 and total rate flow of 50mLmin−1 at various temperatures. The catalyst was cleaned in a hydrogen flow (50cm3 min−1) for 30min after each test. The reactant and product analysis were conducted on line using a Hewlett-Packard 5730A FID gas chromatograph equipped with TCEP (2m, 1/8 in) and Sterling (3m, 1/8 in) columns. Conversion was determined by crossing the reaction temperature and, after each temperature, the catalyst was cleaned in a hydrogen flow (50cm3 min−1) for 30min. The kinetic study was performed at 100°C with a catalyst sample of 0.025g. The catalyst was flowed with 1% C6H6/H2 +He as a reactant mixture (100cm3 min−1). Helium (99.999%) was used as received from Air Liquide. The reaction products were analyzed as described above and the conversion was maintained below 3%. 2.4 Study of the effect of calcination on catalyst reactivity The freshly prepared catalyst was calcined at 400°C/air (flow rate of 50mLmin−1 with a heating rate 7.5°Cmin−1) for various times and stored under argon. Notation was Ni0 REF and Ni0 CALCxH for as-prepared and calcined samples respectively, where xH represents the time of calcination in hours. Oxidized nickel was denoted as NiOair. Due to contamination of nickel by moisture during handling, all samples were submitted to in situ standard hydrogen pre-treatment (see above) before chemisorption and catalysis experiments. The overall protocol of the study is reported in Scheme 1 . We underline that after the hydrogen pre-treatment, the reference sample contained Ni0 only whereas the calcined samples comprised both Ni0 and NiO species. This means that in each sample Ni0 is the sum of residual metallic nickel (not oxidized by the 400°C/air treatment) plus that due to the partial reduction of NiOair during the standard hydrogen pre-treatment. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Degree of reduction of nickel In our previous study [1] XRD experiments evidenced the pattern of the Ni0 phase in a reference Ni/SiO2 catalyst where the metal content was of 3%. After calcination at 250°C/2h, this signal was still present with a lower intensity due to oxidation of metallic nickel. As to the signal of the expected nickel oxidized phases, it was not detected: absence of NiO species was ascribed to formation of amorphous phases. We assumed same mechanisms in the present study with the 1%Ni catalyst. Variation in the proportions metallic/oxidized phases was determined chemically. The degree of reduction was measured by O2 chemisorption. It decreased monotonously with the time of previous exposure to air (Table 1 ). The obtained samples were partly oxidized, reduced and unreduced nickel particles coexisting in various proportions. The rate of oxidation of metallic nickel is remarkably slow: the degree of reduction is still of 59.1% after 24h of calcination at 400°C. It is well established that various nickel silicates are formed during calcination of silica supported nickel catalysts [15,16]. Their stability is related to the strength of metal-support interactions [17,18]. These species probably also formed with the 1%Ni catalyst, however, the low nickel content did not allow their physical characterization. Note that the metal surface area of Ni0 in calcined samples comes from metallic phase not oxidized by the calcination treatment plus that due to the partial reduction of NiOair during the standard pre-treatment with H2/300°C/2h (see Scheme 1). 3.2 H2 adsorption studies Previous studies showed that the bare support did not adsorb hydrogen whereas the metal catalyst did [1]. The amounts of hydrogen adsorbed gradually decreased with diminishing degree of reduction (Table 1). The reference catalyst adsorbed 1010mmolg−1 Ni of hydrogen. The uptake dropped to 740mmolg−1 Ni when the degree of oxidation decreased to 59.1% (corresponding to 24h of oxidative pre-treatment). When a calcined sample is diluted with the support, it adsorbed some additional hydrogen: 941 instead of 842 740mmolg−1 Ni for Ni0 16H, i. e. a little increase of 10.5%. Less hydrogen adsorbed is a consequence of the presence of unreduced nickel in the calcined samples. The unreduced Ni2+ or NiO species formed after calcination adsorb H2 only to a smaller extent (or not at all) as compared to Ni0 [14]. Assuming that H2 is practically adsorbed on reduced nickel only, we have re-calculated the amounts of hydrogen adsorbed by metallic nickel in the samples. Strikingly, these amounts increased with increasing degree of oxidation. The augmentation of the H2 uptake is up to 25% (e.g.1252 against 1010mmolg−1 Ni 0 after 24h of calcination). Presence of unreduced nickel enhanced the metallic surface area. Dilution also promoted the metallic surface area to some extent: for Ni0 CALC16H it passed from 1173 to 1310mmolg−1 Ni 0, that is an augmentation of around 12%. Increase in metal surface area is ascribable to migration of the metal phase during the calcination. In the initial Ni0 REF sample, there existed instable nickel atoms, less interacting with the support, and also more prone to oxidation in air/400°C. The NiO entities formed moved to support new receiving sites, contributing to better metal dispersion. Migration of supported NiO to more stable sites during calcination has been reported and the intensity of the effect on the particle size depended on the thermal treatment and metal loading [14,19,20]. Stable NiO species formed (silicate, aluminate, …) cannot be reduced even under severe reducing conditions [14–16,20]. In turn, they may serve as anchors for Ni0 atoms during the subsequent hydrothermal treatment. As a result they act as a diluent in the Ni0 surface, thereby reducing the size of Ni ensembles [20,21]. The unreduced Ni therefore played a similar role to that of copper in Ni-Cu alloys [22]. Diluting mechanically Ni0 CALC16H with SiO2 led to some increase of the hydrogen uptake (12%). Since the mixture was subsequently reduced by the standard H2/300°C/2h treatment, migration of Ni0 particles to new receiving SiO2 sites is not likely. The mobility of a metal on an oxide surface is lower than that of an oxide [23]. The Ni0 particles rather have been re-dispersed due to the grinding procedure during the mixing, by breaking of metal particles to smaller ones. Choi et al. [8] stressed on possible degradation of a metal phase during its dilution on a support by too harsh mechanical grinding. The local catalyst composition and structure can change drastically depending on the types of diluents, severity of mixing (grinding procedure) and subsequent thermal treatment for catalyst [24]. 3.3 H2-TPD studies We have previously evidenced that the bare support desorbs hydrogen after H2/400°C reducing treatment [1]. The amounts desorbed substantially increased in the presence of nickel. Dissociative adsorption of hydrogen by non reducible oxides has been reported in earlier studies [25,26]. Surface H atoms adsorbed on silica has also been obtained catalytically by Teichner et al. [27,28]. Initially, SiO2 and a catalyst in close contact were treated with H2 at 430°C for 12h. After isolating, the treated silica was flowed with ethylene at 25 or 110°C. This led to ethane due to H atoms remaining on the oxide solid. The hydrogenation of ethylene was not observed in the absence of the catalyst during the hydro-pretreatment. Similar conclusions were reported later by Rajagopal et al. [29]. These experiments were commented by Prins [5] in his critical review on the hydrogen spillover. The author admitted that high temperature treatment of non reducible oxides may create defects on which H atoms may be anchored. In many of our previous studies on nickel based catalysts [e.g. [1,30,31]] we showed that the amounts of hydrogen desorbed were higher than that adsorbed and these amounts augmented again after dilution by the support. Similar studies were also reported by Benseradj et al. [32]: Rh/Al2O3 catalyst desorbed more hydrogen after dilution by alumina or other oxides. Indeed, total amounts of hydrogen desorbed by the catalyst were 120.4mmolg−1 cat and increased to 130.4, 148.0, 211.6 and 347.5mmolg−1 cat after dilution by silica, alumina, activated carbon and HY zeolite respectively. The hydrogen desorbed at high temperatures was attributed to the spillover effect. By the way, effect of a metal on surface diffusion of H atoms on non reducible oxides has been also reported: at 140°C, the diffusion coefficient of hydrogen atoms is 10−4–10−5 cm2 s−1 for isolated SiO2 and 1.5cm2 s−1 for SiO2 in Pd/SiO2 [2]. These considerations allowed us to ascribe the high temperatures peaks in H2-TPD experiments to hydrogen retained in the silica support during the thermal treatment under H2. This treatment has activated support defects or created new ones on which hydrogen molecules or atoms strongly adsorbed. As to the increase of the amounts of hydrogen stored in the presence of nickel it was ascribed to more hydrogen molecules dissociated by the metal particles then incorporated to the support on the H atoms acceptors sites. The H2-TPD profiles of catalysts presently examined showed that hydrogen desorption comprised two main peaks of temperature whether the sample was pre-oxidized or not (Fig. 1 ). The similarity of the temperature profiles suggests similar mechanisms of the adsorption/desorption processes. The first peak appeared from room temperature with a maximum temperature arising at ∼150°C then vanishing above 300°C. It was ascribed to hydrogen weakly adsorbed to nickel active sites. The maximum temperature is decreased to around 130°C for calcined samples. This weakening of the metal-hydrogen bonding cannot be ascribed to increased particle size because it rather diminished (the H2 uptake increased, Table 1). Also we ascribed decreased maximum temperature peak to presence of NiO species on which Ni0 species are anchored: the Ni2+ ions may exert an electron withdrawal on the metallic particles rendering easier the release of the H atoms bonded. This electronic effect is also invoked for the catalytic activity in benzene hydrogenation described below. The second desorption peak appeared at higher temperatures with maximum desorption at ∼500°C as a result of a strong adsorption. The maximum temperature slightly increased with the time of calcination. It is accompanied by a shoulder except for the sample calcined for 4h. The lower temperature of this shoulder indicated a medium strength of the corresponding desorption sites. The H2-TPD performed for diluted catalyst is very similar to those from the calcined catalysts. That is to say, the TPD profile of this catalyst also showed two main domains of desorption, in low (<300°C) and high temperature ranges, respectively. The oxidizing treatment is detrimental to the height of the reservoir (Table 1). The amount of H2 desorbed by the reference sample substantially decreased from 3089 to 2584mmolg−1 Ni for degree of reduction of 90.0 and 80.5% respectively. It remained constant at lower degrees (71.8–59.1%). In contrast, the reservoir sharply increased when the calcined catalyst is diluted with silica, increasing from 1682 to 3149mmolg−1 Ni for Ni0 CALC16H, it is multiplied by 2.7. Thermal effect of calcination would have to oxidize part of defects or metal impurities, and even to remove surface hydroxyls, all potential hosts for H spilt-over species. It increased with the time of calcination. The subsequent H2/300°C treatment was not strong enough to regenerate the H-receiving sites. Contrary to that, in the diluted sample, added silica supplied new active sites for the hydrogen reservoir which therefore augmented after the mixing of the reference catalyst with the support. Close inspection of results reported in Table 1 shows that the amounts of hydrogen desorbed at low temperature (<300°C) are roughly similar to that adsorbed except for the diluted sample (Table 1). This coincidence suggests that this type of hydrogen corresponds to the active species in hydrogenation reactions. As to the desorption occurring at higher temperature (Fig. 1) it was ascribed to hydrogen spillover incorporated in the support as discussed above. The amounts desorbed are sharply increased by dilution of the catalyst with the support. Effect of calcination on spilt-over species has not been reported to our knowledge. Also it is worthy to get back to Miller et al. [9] invoked in our introduction. The authors reported that pre-calcination decreased the amounts of hydrogen desorbed in the high temperature domain for Pt/zeolite catalysts. They ascribed this hydrogen, not to the spillover effect, but to the decomposition of NH3 that had been adsorbed on the acid sites of the support during catalyst preparation with the Pt(NH3)4Cl2 precursor. We also showed that N2H4 was incorporated to the support during the preparation of supported hydrazine catalysts [16]. The as-received catalyst decomposed during a subsequent heat treatment, also H2 +N2 or N2 alone were detected. Similar decomposition, if any, may have occurred with the initial heating in air of the Ni0 REF catalysts (Scheme 1). As to the subsequent H2/300°C treatment it should have incorporated hydrogen atoms in the support. Therefore high temperature hydrogen evidenced in our H2-TPD experiments is undoubtedly ascribable to hydrogen spillover, not to the decomposition of N2H4. To conclude, the TPD experiments evidenced the presence of hydrogen species weakly bonded to the support and identified as active sites for hydrogenation reactions. They also showed that the amounts of H atoms desorbing at high temperatures significantly decreased after calcination due to poisoning of the hydrogen receiving sites whereas they increased after dilution of the catalyst with the support due to increased hydrogen receiving sites. 3.4 Catalytic activity The activity of calcined and non calcined catalysts were determined after a standard pre-treatment of H2/300°C. Quasi steady-state and stable activity was rapidly reached. The catalysts were selective to cyclohexane, only traces of cyclohexene and methylcyclopentane were detected. The results obtained are reported in Figs. 2 and 3 and Table 2 . The catalysts exhibited a maximum of conversion as a function of the reaction temperature (Fig. 2). Moreover, this maximum shifts towards higher temperatures for the diluted catalyst, from 120 to 140°C. This shift was also reported in the literature [33]. In fact, rather than a maximum, a plateau was obtained which smoothly decreased with the reaction temperature. The plateau profile indicated a high activity of the catalyst. Existence of maximum activity with increasing temperature has been long known for the hydrogenation of benzene by metal catalysts [33] and verified in a great number of articles since then, e.g. [20]. We also observed this phenomenom in many of our studies for mono and bimetallic nickel based catalysts. It is admitted that a positive influence of the reaction kinetics prevails at the lower temperatures, whereas at the higher temperatures, the thermodynamic effect of the reaction was dominating and the conversion decreased, e.g. [34,35]. Benzene would be adsorbed on nickel via π bonding [34]. A reversible maximum for benzene hydrogenation against reaction temperature has been frequently reported [35–37]. In the high temperature domain, decreased activity with temperature is accounted for by competitive adsorption of the reactant molecules: the surface coverage by benzene molecules decreased at the higher temperatures, e.g. [38,39]. The reaction orders were determined at 100°C at around 3% of conversion. Assuming the empirical rate equation: r=k PH m PB n where k is the rate constant, the partial orders m and n of hydrogen and benzene respectively were determined. Values of 0.98 and 2.14 were obtained for m and n respectively (Figures not reported, see Supplementary information). The same values of m and n were also found for other SiO2 supported nickel catalysts prepared by the hydrazine method [40]. If the order value for hydrogen is in good accordance with that observed for classically prepared catalysts (in the range 0.3–2.3) [31,34,41], for benzene it is by far greater (in the range 0 to −1) [31,39,42]. Such a significant negative value is an indication of a strong adsorption of benzene on the catalyst surface [31]. The specific activity increases with the diminution of the degree of reduction (Fig. 2). TOF’s also sharply increased with decreasing degree of reduction as reported in Table 2 at different reaction temperatures. The calcined catalysts exhibited a higher activity than the non-calcined catalyst, in good accordance with increasing metal surface area as determined by hydrogen adsorption (Table 1). Experimental energies of activation in the temperature range 75–120°C were determined by the Arrhenius method (see Supplementary information). The energy of activation was 34.2kJmol−1 for Ni0 REF and a little decreased for calcined samples, e. g. 32.7kJmol−1 for Ni0 CALC16H. Our H2-TPD experiments showed that calcination enhanced the reactivity of H atoms desorbing from nickel at low temperature. Such a reactivity was ascribed to an electronic interaction between metallic and oxidized nickel species. We conclude that enhanced activity in benzene hydrogenation after calcination would be due, at least partly, to enhanced reactivity of the H2 reactant molecules at the metal surface. These findings are in agreement with papers on hydrogenation of benzene over classical nickel catalysts. The TOF was found influenced by the degree of nickel reduction. Certain authors suggested that the effect of oxidizing pre-treatment may be related to the presence of unreduced nickel for benzene hydrogenation [20–22]. They believe that unreduced nickel decreased the size of the nickel particles required for the adsorption of benzene in planar mode. Martin et al. [43,44] proposed that various phenomena, erroneously attributed to particle size effects in aromatic molecules hydrogenation, in fact result from the Ni0-Ni2+ interaction. We infer that both H2 and C6H6 reactant molecules may be strongly activated on metallic nickel in the presence of unreduced nickel. Recall that electronic effects were invoked to explain the role of surface acidity in aromatic molecules hydrogenation by metal supported catalysts: when metal particles are in contact with acid sites they become electron deficient and more active [39]. The activity is the highest when the catalyst is diluted with the support (Fig. 3). The energy of activation in the temperature range 75–120°C was 25.4kJmol−1, lower than that of the non diluted sample. Moreover, in contrast with the non calcined sample, it is not related to the increase of metallic surface area (Table 1). The activity is in effect multiplied by 2.0–2.4 in the temperature range 75°C–90°C investigated whereas the hydrogen uptake is multiplied by ∼1.1 only. Effect of dilution of metal supported catalysts in aromatics hydrogenation has long been discussed and was ascribed to the spillover effect [2,3]. Against spillover effect, in aromatic molecules hydrogenation, the main argument is related to the exothermicity of the reaction [5], notably at high conversion (≥20%) which is the case in many instances. The results obtained are considered as unreliable because the reaction is not isothermal and leads to underestimation of the activity of the undiluted catalyst [10]. Impurities may also have distorted the results. In the present study and according to this criterion, conversion of about 20% at 75°C may allow to consider the occurrence of the spillover. At this conversion TOF of the diluted catalyst is double that of the undiluted catalysts (Table 2). Extrapolating at lower conversion (<10%) one observes that the gap in activity with the diluted catalyst is maintained. Since the support was highly crystallized, relays for the hydrogen spillover would be defects. Metal impurities of the support may also play a similar role. Coke, eventually remaining on the catalysts after cleaning (see Experimental), is not a good candidate for this role because we found it did not contain graphitic carbonaceous material [45], an effective H transport agent [5]. At the higher temperatures where the conversions are ≥40%, the H-spillover mechanism existence was not considered. Calcination increased the catalysts activity. Since, in the mean time, it diminished the number of H-spiltover species on the support, one may think that improved activity is ascribable to the nickel phase, more dispersed and more active as showed our H2-TPD experiments. In contrast, dilution led to sharp increase in activity which could be attributed to the sharp increase of H-species incorporated in the support (multiplied by 2.7). The little increase of the metal surface area (∼10%) after dilution cannot be incriminated. Therefore one is allowed to think to the existence of competitive adsorption and reaction of benzene on nickel and on support for calcined catalysts. The nickel phase would be composed of Ni0-NiOx ensembles. Adsorption of benzene was studied on unsupported metallic nickel and nickel oxide in conditions near that of the hydrogenation [46]. It was established that there is no significant difference between the two adsorbents in the heats of adsorption or the ratios of the total and irreversible adsorption of the hydrocarbon. Fig 4 shows the good correlation between H2 uptake and TOF’s and the fraction of non reduced nickel for non diluted catalysts. In contrast, these trends are not fitted for the diluted catalyst. This corroborates a different mechanism. The significant difference of energy of activation of diluted (25.4kJmol−1) and undiluted (32.7kJmol−1) catalysts strengthens the existence of two reaction paths in benzene hydrogenation on our catalysts. Scheme 2 illustrates these mechanisms. In the model catalyst of Choi et al. [6] the spillover mechanism in benzene hydrogenation is undoubtful: because the Pt metal phase is not accessible to the benzene molecule, the reaction necessarily occurs on the support with the help of H-spilt-over species. Contrary to that, for Primet et al. [47], the hydrogenation of benzene occurs on the metal phase with Pt/zeolite used because the organic molecule was accessible and more strongly adsorbed on the Pt than on the zeolite support. A mix of both mechanisms was reported for Pd [48] and Pt [39] supported on alumina: the hydrogenation reaction would occur on both the metal phase and on the support. Our work suggests that, besides the kinetic parameters (rate and adsorption constants), the degree of oxidation and morphology of the metal phase may be an important factor for the occurrence of the spillover mechanism. 4 Conclusions Ni/SiO2 catalysts prepared by the hydrazine method then calcined at 400°C were studied after a standard treatment in H2/300°C/2h. Metal dispersion increased with increasing calcination time through nickel oxide migration to more stabilizing sites on the support. Hydrogen storage by the support strongly diminished with calcination due to poisoning of the receiving sites of the H-spiltover species. In contrast, dilution of a calcined catalyst by the support led to new adsorption sites for hydrogen and resulted in an increased hydrogen storage. Activity in benzene hydrogenation increased with increasing degree of oxidation of nickel in good accordance with increased metal dispersion. The activity also increased with dilution of the calcined sample by the support and was ascribed to the occurrence of the spillover mechanism. Discussion of the results obtained showed that the mechanism of hydrogenation of benzene is influenced by the degree of reduction of the catalysts. The benzene molecule may be competitively adsorbed and hydrogenated on the support or on the nickel phase. Calcination treatment which decreases the number of H-spilover species on the support favors the reaction occurring on the nickel phase. Dilution of the catalyst by the support, in contrast, increased the number of H-spilover species on the support and also favored the hydrogen spillover mechanism. The metal active phase would be composed of an ensemble of Ni0 and NiOx species interacting with the support. coredata.dc:description: The chemisorption and hydrogenating properties of Ni/SiO2 catalysts prepared by the hydrazine method then calcined at 400°C with various times were investigated. Metal dispersion and activity in benzene hydrogenation increased with increasing calcination time whereas desorbed amounts of hydrogen significantly decreased. Dilution of a calcined sample by the support led to a sharp increase of both hydrogen storage by the support and catalytic activity. Metal dispersion and hydrogen storage capacity influenced the reaction mechanisms of hydrogenation of benzene which, therefore, is believed to occur on the metal phase or/and on the support by the hydrogen spillover mechanism. The metal active phase would be composed of an ensemble of metallic and oxidized nickel species.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of oxidative pre-treatment on hydrogen spillover for a Ni/SiO2 catalyst
